page-0.title:
Scaling Down to Zero:
The Need to Reconsider Negative Emissions Technologies

text: Because of the rapid rise in global temperatures, mitigating climate change will be one of the greatest challenges of this century. But many of the technologies being developed in response to this crisis may in fact reinforce historic drivers of global warming.

In a race against the clock, climate governance is embracing a variety of geoengineering technologies to eliminate some of these emissions. However, given that these solutions aren’t being paired with meaningful fossil fuel reductions, they will most likely be used to justify continuing business-as-usual practices.
page-2.hoverText: Geoengineering: To make a large-scale effort to modify the earth or its environment, especially to counteract global warming

text: In this project, you will see some of the nuances of a widely proposed CO2 removal technology called Bioenergy with Carbon Capture and Storage, or BECCS. The U.S. and U.K. governments are heavily promoting BECCS to mitigate future emissions, which is why it’s important to take a critical look now.
Crops capture C02, crops burned, CO2 stored underground

This is one of the few working facilities, the Decatur ethanol refinery, owned by one of the largest agribusiness in the world and funded by the Department of Energy. It’s not a negative emitter, since it’s powered by fossil fuels and only captures 16% of carbon emitted <sup>2</sup>.
page-5.summary: Only a few plants exist worldwide

page-6.text: Let’s look at historic greenhouse gas emissions to understand the role BECCS might play in the future.

page-7.text: One gigaton = one billion tons, measuring global emissions
page-7.annotation: Edison invents the central power station in 1882. At this time, global GHG emissions were nearing only 1 gigaton.

page-8.annotation: Emissions quickly rise. But not all were evenly produced; by 1970, the U.S. and U.K. were responsible for 75% of emissions worldwide.
page-8.hoverText: Given this stark statistic, the concept of 'Common But Differentiated Responsibility' emerged, recognizing the historical responsibility of industrialized countries for global environmental problems, and implying they take far-reaching measures in responding meaningfully to such problems <sup>3</sup>.

page-9.annotation: Today global emissions have reached more than 35 gigatons per year, and are projected to continue.

page-10.annotation: This accumulation of emissions corresponds to a rise in temperature of 2°F. If we compare this rise to body temperature, a 2°F increase signals a problem.

page-11.annotation: Now let’s look forward to possible future pathways.

page-12.annotation: Absent any changes, temperatures are set to rise by at least 8°F. This is referred to as baseline.

page-13.annotation: If all current climate mitigation policies are enforced, the trajectory would look something like this: temperatures might rise by about 5°F.

page-14.annotation: Finally, there are pathways that lead us to stay below a 4°F rise, corresponding to 1.5°C and 2°C, a threshold that will help us avoid unpredictable climate reactions.

page-15.annotation: One reason to be concerned about BECCS in particular is because it is one of the major players in these pathways. In fact of the 116 scenarios that would most likely keep global temperatures below 1.5 degrees, BECCS is included in 80% of them.

text: One reason is the amount of resources BECCS would require. Let's look at how much land would be needed for the crop plantations and factories.
page-16.summary: So why should we be concerned about this?

text: See more critiques or jump to conclusion?

Land use is just one of many concerning factors that isn’t often discussed by the entities promoting BECCS, which include fossil fuel companies, like Shell. Further concerns surround the storage (or lack thereof) of liquid CO2; some of these companies are already using the CO2 to extract crude oil from an otherwise depleted field, a process called Enhanced Oil Recovery.
Additionally, BECCS models often don't account for the entire carbon lifecycle.
page-21.summary: BECCS is not a negative emitter

text: BECCS relies on industrial agriculture, which itself is responsible for ⅓ of all greenhouse gas emissions.

page-23.text: There are many other alternative pathways that don’t rely on risky interventions, and have existed for centuries. Since BECCS uses industrial agriculture, we can start by transforming that system. Let's look at one example.

text: Agroecology is the practice of sustainable farming based on traditional methods. It’s also a political movement, with an aim to make traditional agriculture more economically viable and autonomous for small-scale farmers.

Most of these farmers already use agroecology, and they feed an estimated 70% of the population while using less than a quarter of agricultural land. Agroecology embraces a holistic approach to the food system, rather than only focusing on individual crop yields.
If we reject technologies like BECCS while simultaneously phasing out fossil fuels, we will begin to see the abundance of solutions that lay within reach.
